<s>IIII. As the intervals of those fits are all supposed equal; 
are totally independent of refracting or reflecting surfaces, 
& are common to all colours; as many red rays for 
instance will fall on any particular point of surface disposed 
for transmission as for reflection; therefore an equal 
number of all those red rays that fall on any particular 
spot should be transmitted as that of those that are reflected; 
but we find by experiment, that where Red rays are 
reflected, none are transmitted, & <u>vice versa <\u>; the same 
will hold true with respect to all the other colours; 
therfore in all those cases the fits seem ineffectual. 
V. As the intervals of the fits are supposed to occupy 
the 89000th of an inch only; & since light moves at the 
rate of one Million of Miles each Minute in round numbers; it follows 
that more than 33 Millions of Millions of the intervals 
of those fits must pass through any transparent surface 
in every second of time. and since every change of 
position of the Lenses of even the 89000th part of one 
inch in any direction whatever, must either change the 
thickness of the plate of Air with respect to the rays 
falling on it, or its distance from the luminous body; 
in either case the appearances of the prismatic rings 
must be incessantly varying; insomuch that it would be im-
possible to prevent such tremor taking place as would 
completely mix the colours, & destroy their prismatic 
appearance; but we find that the same obliquity 
of the incident light, & the same elevation of the Eye is 
preserved; no removal of the lenses has any effect 
in changing the appearance of those Rings.
VI. one other objection remains, which alone appears to 
be conclusive against the Theory. The plate of Air can 
have no share whatever in the formation of prismatic 
rings; because if the apparatus in which they are formed 
is placed under the glass receiver of an Air pump and 
the Air exausted as compleately as the most improved 
construction of an Airpump is capable of, no diminution
